article:
Philo Farnsworth, the inventor of one of the country's greatest machines was actually born in a log cabin,  _  to high school on horse back and without  _  of university degree(indeed, at age 14), thought of the idea of electronic television. In 1906 Farnsworth was born in a community near Beaver City, Utah,  _  by his grandfather.  _  he was 12, his family moved to a ranch  in Rigby, Idaho, which was four miles from, the nearest high school,  _  necessitating his daily horseback rides. Because he was interested in the electron and electricity, he persuaded his chemistry teacher, Justin Tolman, to give him  _  instruction and to allow him to listen to a senior course.
The death of his father forced him to leave at the end of his second year, but, as it  turned out  , at no great intellectual cost. There were, at the time, no more than a handful of men  _  the planet who could have understood Farnsworth's idea for building an electronic television system, and it's  _  that any of them were at this local community. One such man was Vladimir Zworykin who had moved to the US from Russia with a Ph. D in electrical engineering. He went to work for Westinghouse with a dream of building an all-electronic television system. But he wasn't  _  to do so.
